pros: Tons of opportunity, great benefits, great people.
cons: System of care is hard, lots of documentation, senior leadership is disconnected

pros: Incredible team, work from home, great application..

pros: Community mental health, feeling of mutual commitment

job_title: Resident Caretaker in Bellows Falls, VT
pros: it is a rewarding job. you can make a difference in someones life.
cons: like with any job right now it is a little more difficult to find coverage.

review_title: Don't work here unless you are a Democrat.
pros: Individual teams become really tight. Some of the best people I have ever worked with.
cons: Vaccine mandates, higher ups who pretend really hard to listen but really dont. Politics infused with the company goals.

pros: Great benefits with a lot of paid time off
cons: It is community mental health, so the pay is not the best

job_title: Manager of Developmental Services in Springfield, VT

review_title: Minimal training, great expectations including expected overtime, no lunch breaks and very little salary.
pros: Honestly, it was a nightmare from beginning to end.
cons: A paperwork nightmare and insufficient training to learn it.  Supervision was heavy handed and demeaning, and could not in way be considered "clinical" as it was designated. I witnessed staff being yelled at in front of clients and being bullied.   The system was going from paper to computer and there was very little training offered to accommodate the transition.

pros: The work that is done to help individuals and families to live healthier lives! The leave time and benefits are amazing.  I truly feel HCRS cares about my needs as well as the needs of my family. For example, I have never worked for an agency where we are allowed "snow days", if we don't feel safe driving we are able to use leave, if your child doesn't have school you are also able to use leave for this reason.
cons: The downside is the limited upwards movement in my position.

pros: Working with the clients is rewarding and enjoyable

review_title: Retiring after a wonderful 30 years at HCRS
pros:
Opportunities to grow, be creative, team
All throughout career my talents have been recognized and encouraged
Never get bored
Work with creative, compassionate, human supervisors and staff
"Do the right thing" is a mantra I have heard often
Ever striving to do better, with clients at the center
cons:
Biggest challenge is that behavioral health is underfunded
Communication is a challenge -- something that is a focus

review_title: Great people, good company- not perfect but as human services go, it's a great place to work.
pros:
Good pay & benefits 
Matching 403b
Regular team meetings
Unbelievable resources for certain programs
cons:
Some resistance to feedback from staff
Inconsistent discipline/expectations (favoritism)
Scheduling could be better (done more in advance and with input from staff)

pros: Most of my peers are very nice to work with
cons:
Management and SLT have no idea what their doing. They reward hard working employees with more hard work and just ignore the under performers.

They don't give any positive reinforcement when things are done right. 

Salaries are low.

Wasteful spending of tax payer dollars to furnish group homes with elaborate antique furniture only to be ruined by clients.

pros: Flexible hours. Managers have no idea that staff come and go as we want because they don't monitor.
cons: Management is horrible. They don't back their staff, and throw their staff under the bus to save themselves.

pros: Great place to learn while working on hours to get licensed.
cons: High turnover.  Pay is not especially competitive.

pros: Great people, free CEUs, visible and approachable leadership
cons: Vacation now limited to one week, no 401k match, no raises
